headline: BREAKING: Biden: ‘I’m not walking anything back’ on whether Putin should be in power
author: DML News App
sentences:
We will continue to track the statements of the U.S. president in the most attentive way.”
President Joe Biden is standing by his statement that Russian President Vladimir Putin should not remain in power, saying he was speaking to the Russian people but not calling for regime change in Moscow.https://t.co/IzuB21FDXq
— Washington Examiner (@dcexaminer) March 28, 2022
Lawmakers from both sides of the aisle disputed the “dangerous” statements- even the White House walked back the escalating rhetoric.

Full stop.” pic.twitter.com/KDL1r3BmDV

Republican Rep. Jim Jordan said Biden’s speech in Poland Saturday night was “more than confusing, it’s dangerous.”
“Here’s the president potentially having more war-triggering type language than probably any president in American,” Jordan warned.

“Please, Mr. President, stay on script.”
Sen. Jim Risch (R-ID) reacts to President Joe Biden saying Russian President Vladimir Putin “cannot remain in power,” telling @DanaBashCNN the remark could cause problems in Ukraine as the US tries to de-escalate the conflict.

“We need to be careful and precise in things we say, particularly as commander in chief of our country.”
Sen. James Risch (R-Idaho) on Sunday said Biden’s comment that Putin should not remain in power was “a horrendous gaffe.”
“I wish he would stay on script.

“As you know, and as you have heard us say repeatedly, we do not have a strategy of regime change in Russia – or anywhere else, for that matter.”
Secretary Blinken’s comments come after President Biden’s remarks during his trip in Poland.

STORY: https://t.co/Fmt7HzUbLX pic.twitter.com/LSrQExaaZW
— Washington Examiner (@dcexaminer) March 28, 2022
The Kremlin finally addressed Biden’s declaration that Putin “cannot remain in power” on Monday, noting it was a cause for alarm.

“I think the president, the White House, made the point last night that, quite simply, President Putin cannot be empowered to wage war or engage in aggression against Ukraine or anyone else,” Blinken said during a visit to Jerusalem.

#CNNSOTU pic.twitter.com/PcylOrnQ23
— CNN (@CNN) March 27, 2022
Following the two major gaffes during his trip, social media has been buzzing about invoking the 25th Amendment over Biden’s “dangerous” rhetoric.

Recall, the media called for the 25th amendment when Trump sipped water or walked down ramps carefully.”

@JoeBiden is standing by his statement that Russian President Vladimir Putin should not remain in power, saying he was speaking to the Russian people but not calling for regime change in Moscow.
Almost immediately after Biden’s controversial address, the White House appeared to walk back his comments, denying that Biden was calling for regime change.

Secretary of State Antony Blinken also told reporters Sunday that the US has no plans for regime change in Russia.
“The President’s point was that Putin cannot be allowed to exercise power over his neighbors or the region.
Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said about Biden’s remark, “This is a statement that is certainly alarming.
Recall, the media called for the 25th amendment when Trump sipped water or walked down ramps carefully.
“But I want to make it clear I wasn’t then, nor am I now, articulating a policy change,” he continued.
Honestly, the 25th Amendment was crafted for just such a situation as we are now in with Biden.
He was not discussing Putin’s power in Russia, or regime change,” a White House official said.
All we’d be hearing is that he’s mentally unfit and must be removed under the 25th Amendment.

This behavior is totally unacceptable.”
“It’s more of an aspiration than anything.
Blinken and others, the U.S. does not have a policy of regime change in Russia.

I make no apologies for it.”
“I was talking to the Russian people,” he added.
